title: How does anybody win when one side's baseline is 'You're wrong but you have a right to be wrong' and the other's baseline is 'You're wrong and I will use the power of government to force you to do the right thing'? How can that possibly end? - Quora

response.answer_text: This question is phrased in a way that would interpreted in one way by conservatives, and in another way by liberals, because its terms and assumptions are vague and require interpretation. In particular, “You’re wrong and I will use the power of government to do the right thing?” is phrased as a leading question, implying that to do this will have bad effects, even though it is necessary to use the power of government, and even armed force, to safely police a society, to defend it, and to maintain civil order. Of course, liberals and conservatives would draw the line where it is necessary for the government enforce laws in different places. In addition, “You’re wrong but you have a right to be wrong” would be interpreted differently by liberals and by conservatives. In general, they would draw the lines of “rights” in different places. For example, conservatives would make an exception to this proposition in the case of abortion, while liberals would not. To actually answer the question, in a harmonious society, the tension between these two propositions, which is certainly real, is resolved by each side treating the other as rational beings with whom a compromise can be reached. If it has no longer become possible to compromise, then each side will see the other side as less than rational, and thus deserving of restraint, and what is more, by their own lights, each side will be quite correct in this. In history, this usually ends badly.

How does anybody win when one side’s baseline is “You’re wrong but you have a right to be wrong” and the other’s baseline is “You’re wrong and I will use the power of government to force you to do the right thing”? How can that possibly end? (Thanks for the “ask to answer.”) The situation that the original poster has described is essentially trench warfare. However, it does not accurately reflect the facts on the ground. To wit, the reality of modern democracy is that the vast majority of citizens are perfectly happy to periodically cast a ballot for the proverbial lesser of two evils, after which the oligarchical collective of government picks up the ball and runs with it. Right and wrong are consequently redefined as what the representatives of a majority or a gerrymander-empowered minority say it should be. That is to say, most people believe that when they lose at the ballot box, they lose the right to say what is right and what is wrong until the next election. As a lifelong libertarian, I do not in any way acknowledge the right of other people to be wrong, but neither do I appeal to the power of government to force other people to do what I think is the right thing. Rather, I seek to peacefully coexist with the vast majority of people who usually know the difference between right and wrong, but who choose to defer to the anonymous authority of the crowd, or to the supposedly legitimate powers that be of government. Meanwhile, I choose to speak truth to power, like a voice in the wilderness, and preach to the choir of like-minded libertarians.

response.answer_text: People don’t actually have a right to be wrong. Consider a scenario where someone has the belief that they have the right to practise paedophilia. “You’re wrong but you have a right to be wrong” implies that they have a right to be a paedophile. We could go further and invoke neuroscientific reasons for such people’s practices: Decreased activations were seen in the hypothalamus, dorsal midbrain, dorsolateral prefrontal cortex, and right lateral parietal, right ventrolateral, and right occipital cortices, as well as in the left insula in 13 hetero- and homosexual forensic pedophiles when viewing sexual stimuli as compared to emotional stimuli as compared to teleiophiles (Walter et al., 2007). Based on these findings, it was suggested that the missing sexual interest toward adults could be explained by impairment in subcortical regions associated with the autonomic component of sexual arousal, i.e., lack of activation seen in hypothalamus and dorsal midbrain in pedophilia. Additionally, using a regression analysis approach, the activation in the left DLPFC was inversely correlated with the score on the child abuse subscale of the multiphasic sexual inventory (MSI), indicating also possible alterations of cognitive processing of sexual stimuli in these subjects (Schiffer et al., 2008a,b). The Neurobiology and Psychology of Pedophilia: Recent Advances and Challenges Now, to do so would be an abuse of science, but nevertheless there is a wealth of literature that does exactly this - creating reasons from case-control studies which imply ‘people are the way they are because that’s how they are’. Such determinism removes all responsibility. For anything. Do paedophiles have a right to be paedophiles? Why not? There is nothing wrong with people having opinions. One consequence of opinions is that they imply contrary opinions are wrong, and that’s also fine. Getting the government involved is contextual, certain decisions affect society as a whole, are necessarily made on the governmental level, and good government is responsive to the wishes of its people. What matters is how one chooses to deal with that disagreement: You can fight to promote a narrative or you can seek truth.You can seek to reinforce your beliefs or you can expand them.You can treat people who disagree as the enemy or as people who have a different understanding of how the world works and, as a result, make different predictions regarding the future impacts of various policies.You can obsess over ideological purity or you can search for overlap between opposing sides and, when that fails, “trade” policies that are trivial to yourself and a big deal to someone else for policies that are a big deal to you and trivial to someone else.You can respond to people choosing the former path with despair—a false choice between “giving in” vs. matching their vices—or by setting firm boundaries while also holding the door open for a more healthy relationship in the future.You can be consumed by hate for the things you wish to destroy or you can work to create the world you want.
